blog.name: saccharinemonochromaticism
blog.title: we're on our side
blog.description: anywhere you want to go

summary: for years i was on the side of imagining pre-arrangement era to be strict and uppity aziraphale and cunning crowley outsmarting...
body:
for years i was on the side of imagining pre-arrangement era to be strict and uppity aziraphale and cunning crowley outsmarting each other. read fics of them fighting with blazing weapons and venom and complicated plans. believed they would go all the-night-circus-like in terms of making events to outsmart each other.

but honestly now i’m convinced that pre arrangement they just argued like no other and it always gets to the point where they start throwing logical fallacies and one of them was like OKAY THAT’S ENOUGH let’s have a deal and bam arrangement because they couldn’t have a debate like adults.

summary: Good Omens' David Tennant and Michael Sheen's biggest challenge: Making audiences care about them
title: Good Omens' David Tennant and Michael Sheen's biggest challenge: Making audiences care about them
excerpt: It's not every day an actor gets to step into the shoes of immortal beings, let alone those at the center of a hugely popular fantasy novel. David Tennant and Michael Sheen, genre immortals themselves, will do just that as the stars in the upcoming TV adaptation of Neil Gaiman and Terry Pratchett's Good Omens.

tags: Needless to say tennant as Crowley will be hysterical
But i am just so delighted by sheen all fussy and frumpy as Aziraphale bless him he is so great
summary: Two wonderful things that the upcoming Good Omens show is doing for me
body:
Two wonderful things that the upcoming Good Omens show is doing for me

One: it’s distracting me from the inevitable and bloody demise of my favourite GOT characters in a month or so.

Two: it has reminded me just how absurdly charming I find Michael Sheen, whom I haven’t seen since the second season of Masters of Sex came out ages ago! Anyway, he is a wonderful actor and I ADORE HIM. Give me this show now.

reblog.comment:

summary: I wrote the first 5000 words of Good Omens. And I had the protagonist be a demon called Crowley - who was a demon, but he was a...
text: I wrote the first 5000 words of Good Omens. And I had the protagonist be a demon called Crowley - who was a demon, but he was a lot like Aziraphale. And what Terry did, when he did his draft of this, was to split that character into two. He’d […] gone: Actually, let’s have the cool half of that and the awkward half of that and split them off, into the good and into the evil. And there’s still that strange feeling that it’s one person.
source: Neil Gaiman, SXSW, March 2019 (x)

reblog.comment: Neil Gaiman, SXSW, March 2019 (x)

tags: idk if u have gleaned this
but i'm emo about greenhouses and i Love Them
summary: let crowley have a greenhouse. let him grow plants underneath the glass panes, the sun shining down on luscious, verdant leaves,...
body:
let crowley have a greenhouse.

let him grow plants underneath the glass panes, the sun shining down on luscious, verdant leaves, the scent of the air like ozone: let him remember what eden was, surrounded on every side by viridian splendour, the scent of heat and air and mulch and blossom thick on his tongue. let him stand, at times, in the middle of it all, leaning against his potting table, feeling naught more than the warmth of a sun he once knew millennia ago, the first time it kissed black scales and gave him a scant sliver of the warmth he knew with the Host

let him have his greenhouse.

let him love in it, and laugh in it: let him whisper dark threats to tomatoes and cucumbers, let him murmur evil words to the leaves of pepper plants, let him leave burning words on the skin of every chilli, that it grows riper and heavier with every day that passes.

let him stand in his greenhouse when the rain is falling, so that he can close his eyes and hear the thunder of every drop upon the glass panes, and feel, for just a moment, as if the world is ending.

and let aziraphale come up behind him, press a kiss to his shoulder, and say, “come inside, dear. it’s getting late.”

let him leave his eden behind him, every night, and follow the angel where he leads.
